items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Pillings Lock river gauge. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated this afternoon 22/12/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent and Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water in response to yesterdayâ€™s rainfall. Levels on Derwent Water have peaked again this morning Friday, 22nd December but with more persistent, potentially heavy rain forecast to move through on the 23rd and into 24th of December, it is likely to see further river response and the lake level rise again.

Flooding is affecting locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the shores of Derwent Water.

We will continue to monitor the forecasts and re-issue this alert and associated warnings if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are falling on the River Churn, however continued flooding of low lying land and roads is expected, especially in the Cerney Wick area. Light rain is possible today, 22/12/2023, but not expected. River levels are expected to continue gradually falling over the next few days, but levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated Saturday morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels have risen over the last two days on the River Cherwell following rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Thrupp area. 

Light rain is possible today, 22/12/2023, but should clear away by the afternoon. River levels look to have stabilised, and we expect to see them start to lower slightly over the next 24 hours.

We are monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated Saturday morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels are now steady but remain high at Cae Howel river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may still be affected include Llanymynech.

Peaks: Llanymynech peaked at 3.38m on Tuesday, 19/12/23; Cae Howel peaked at 3.81m on Wednesday, 20/12/2023.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00am, 23/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high around Malton and Low Marishes due to recent persistent rainfall, but continue to fall slowly. Areas most at risk include low lying land around Low Marishes and Yedingham. River levels in Malton are continuing to fall below levels of concern although high groundwater remains an issue. We continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00am on Saturday 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high but steady on the River Glyme, therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Woodstock area. River levels on the River Evenlode are expected to be within banks. Light rain is possible today, 22/12/2023, but should clear away by the afternoon. River levels are expected to remain high on the River Glyme for the next few days, and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated Saturday morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are still high on the River Thames. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible, especially in the Abingdon area. 

Light rain is possible today, 22/12/2023, but should clear away by the afternoon. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated Saturday morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high but steady on the River Thames, Seacourt Stream and Bulstake Stream. 
The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, however levels has started to slowly fall. 

Light rain is possible today, 22/12/2023, but should clear away by the afternoon. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling over the next couple of days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated Saturday morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message:
River levels at our East Stoke gauge remain high but are slowly falling and our Stinsford gauge levels are also falling slowly, but this alert is likely to remain in force for at least the next 2 days.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area. The forecast is for very little rain this evening and over the week. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 24/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have fallen back across Cranborne Chase, but levels will remain high for some time. Some minor roads, especially in valley bottoms, are likely to be flooded for up to two days after rainfall. 
Check any property level flood resilience measures including pumps, flood barriers and airbrick cover that you may have in place and replenish stocks of sand bags. 
The weather forecast up to the New Year is for limited amounts of rainfall which makes further property flooding unlikely until into the new year when a more unsettled period is expected.
Environment Agency staff will monitor groundwater levels over the holiday and this message will be updated every 48 hours or as the situation changes. The next update will be on Friday 22nd December.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels are now falling very slowly but remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge following heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00am, 23/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Avon and tributaries
items.message:
River levels remain high in the Middle Hampshire Avon and its Tributaries but are starting to slowly recede.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 24/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are currently high but steady on the River Thames. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially along the river near Shifford and Eynsham Locks. 

Light rain is possible today, 22/12/2023, but should clear away by the afternoon. River levels are forecast to continue falling over the next couple of days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated Saturday morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the River Ray following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, particularly in the Arncott and Islip areas. 

Light rain is possible today, 22/12/2023, but should clear away by the afternoon. River levels look to have stabilised, and we expect to see them start to lower slightly over the next 24 hours in the Lower Arncott area. Around Islip we expect river levels to remain steady over the next 24 hours.

We are monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated Saturday morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Blunsdon Brook, Water Eaton Brook, Marston Meysey Brook, Share Ditch, Bydemill Brook, Westrop Brook, Downington Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are currently high but starting to fall on the River Thames and small tributaries around Calcott. Water is expected to remain in low lying land and roads, but the river is expected to be flowing within its banks. 

Light rain is possible today, 22/12/2023, but should clear away by the afternoon. We expect river levels to continue to gradually fall over the next few days. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated Saturday morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Friday 22nd December and into the weekend. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to the natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.  Water levels also remain high around Wayford Bridge and Hoveton Broad. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Saturday 23rd December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Hull catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high on Beverley and Barmston Drain, Frodingham Beck, the River Hull and Roam Drain due to recent prolonged rainfall and elevated groundwater levels. Areas most at risk are around the rivers and drains between Frodingham Bridge and the Wilfholme area including low lying land around Hempholme. Levels are expected to stay high for several days. We continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 08:00am on Saturday 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high but steady and starting to fall on the River Thame. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Thame, Stadhampton and Dorchester areas. 

Light rain is possible today, 22/12/2023, but should clear away by the afternoon.  River levels are expected to remain high over the next couple of days. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated Saturday morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels remain high on the Lower River Derwent at Thornton Lock and Elvington due to recent persistent rainfall. We expect levels to remain high for the next few days but to continue falling slowly. Levels at Buttercrambe and Stamford Bridge have continued to fall and are below levels of concern, but floodwater is likely to remain on low lying land for a number of days. We are monitoring levels closely and have staff checking flood defences in the area. Continue acting on your flood plan. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00am on Saturday 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are remaining high in the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon and tributaries and additional significant contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels.

Levels are forecast to remain above the Flood Alert level.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 24/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels have fallen back across the West of Dorset area but levels will remain high for some time. Some minor roads, especially in valley bottoms, are likely to be flooded for up to two days after rainfall. 
Check any property level flood resilience measures including pumps, flood barriers and airbrick cover that you may have in place and replenish stocks of sand bags. 
The weather forecast up to the New Year is for limited amounts of rainfall which makes further property flooding unlikely until into the new year when a more unsettled period is expected.
Environment Agency staff will monitor groundwater levels over the holiday and this message will be updated every 48 hours or as the situation changes. The next update will be on Friday 22nd December.

items.message:
River levels are remaining high but starting to recede on the River Piddle following the recent rainfall and additional contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels.

Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area. The forecast is for very little rain this evening and over the week. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 24/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels are now falling at the Rodington and Walcot river gauges but remain high at Walcot as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.

We expect river levels to remain high for the next day or two.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00am, 23/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. Light rainfall is forecast over the coming days, but we do not expect this to have a significant impact on river levels. 

We continue to monitor the situation and the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. "

items.description: The River Waveney from Diss and the River Dove to Ellingham, including Bungay
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely to remain until tomorrow, Saturday 23rd December. We are currently seeing higher river levels than normal in the area of Diss. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for dry conditions today, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message tomorrow morning, Saturday 23rd December.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
The Groundwater flood alert in the Upper Og Valley is no longer in force. 

Groundwater levels have fallen below the level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater. Groundwater levels are expected to continue to fall slowly over the next few days. Groundwater levels in this area are more responsive to individual rainfall events, and therefore remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We will continue to monitor the groundwater levels and reissue this alert if required.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels remain high but are slowly falling on the Chertsey Bourne following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Chertsey area. It is forecast to be mostly dry overnight, 22/12/23 and into tomorrow.  We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall over the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.01m and stable. This level is being maintained by water being pumped off the moor.

The pumping station drain level is 7.97m and falling steadily in response to pumping activities. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.30m, from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, and from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m. Property flooding is expected when this level exceeds 8.35m.

Blustery conditions and occasional showers sometimes with strong winds are forecast for the rest of the week.

We are currently pumping at Westover and Huish Episcopi pumping stations and will continue to clear as much water from the moors as river levels allow. Please remain mindful of local water levels and do not attempt to drive, cycle or walk through flood water.

Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on closed roads.

This message will be updated by 1pm on Saturday 23/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides though windy conditions will continue for the next few days.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Friday 22nd December, and into the weekend. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to the natural tide-locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Water levels also remain high around Wayford Bridge and Hoveton Broad. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Saturday 23rd December, or as the situation changes.

High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to the natural tide-locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. Water levels also remain high around Wayford Bridge and Hoveton Broad. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Saturday 23rd December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: In Hambledon, groundwater levels are very high and continue to slowly rise. Since Tuesday 19/12/2023, the level at our borehole at Whitedale Farm has risen by 33cm. Cellar flooding is affecting a number of properties on West and East Street. Groundwater is inundating the sewerage system and water is beginning to push up through manholes. Flood water is affecting Fareham Road, and the football pitch is being affected by a mixture of groundwater and sewerage. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday (24/12/2023), mostly dry weather is forecast. Groundwater levels are expected to peak over the weekend. From Monday 25/12/2023 to Tuesday 26/12/2023, there is a return to unsettled weather with up to 20mm of rain forecast in Hampshire. An increased number of properties in Hambledon are expected to experience cellar flooding when further heavy rain affects the area. We are liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group and continue to monitor the situation. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on 27/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high and fairly stable. The Idsworth and Chalton Lavants are both flowing. Water is affecting the ford in Rowlands Castle and minor flooding impacts are affecting roads in the area. Pumps which prevent water from entering property will be required for a small number of properties. Surface water flooding may occur during heavier rain events. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday (24/12/2023), the weather is forecast to be mostly dry. However, from Monday (25/12/2023) to Tuesday (26/12/2023), the weather turns more unsettled again with up to 20mm forecast in Hampshire. Groundwater levels are expected to remain high for the next few weeks. Increased road and cellar flooding is likely after the next heavy rainfall event. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please continue to be prepared. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 27/12/2023.

items.description: Tidal River Stour area from Fordwich to Stonar Cut
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water may remain. No further flooding is expected over the weekend. We will continue to monitor the river and tide levels closely.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are slowly rising in response to recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.
The groundwater level at Longacre is higher than normal for this time of year and levels are slowly rising. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 29/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churnet and River Tean
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Leek river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today 22/12/2023. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to rise until tomorrow 23/12/2013. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tributaries of the lower River Witham from Blankney to Sleaford

floodArea.riverOrSea: Kyme Eau, River Slea, Billinghay Skirth, Ruskington Beck, Old River Slea and Leasingham Beck

items.message: River levels are gradually falling, they do however remain high in the Blankney to Sleaford area. Rainfall from the last week will keep river levels high for the next few days. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline in the morning on 23rd December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Hull Central catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Beverley and Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Hull due to recent rainfall, high groundwater levels and the effect of the tides. Flooding may affect locations near the Beverley and Barmston Drain and River Hull, with low lying land expected to be most affected, including the central River Hull area around Arram, Tickton, Beverley, and Dunswell. River levels are expected to remain high for a number of days. We are in the area operating pumping stations and checking defences, as well as operating flood defences across the wider catchment area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00am on Saturday 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels are expected to remain high, but steady at the Torksey gauge through today, 22/12/2023, and over the next few days as a result of high tides. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00 tomorrow morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
Lower Derwent in Derbyshire
items.message:
"River levels are rising at the Church Wilne river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to begin from 21:00 22/12/2023 and over the next 48 hours, .  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Church Wilne, Draycott, and Wilne Lane between Draycott and Sawley.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to rise.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes."

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message: River levels remain high after Tuesdayâ€™s rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. Access to properties in Berry Lane, Godmanchester, may also be affected. The weather forecast is unsettled but mostly dry over the weekend, which should allow river levels to start falling. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, 23/12/23.

items.description: Weymouth Rivers and Streams
Lower River Cam in Cambridgeshire
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The weather forecast remains unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to continue falling. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are slowly rising on the River Windrush however continued flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Newbridge area near the confluence with the Thames. 

Light rain is possible today, 22/12/2023, but should clear away by the afternoon. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 

We are monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated Saturday morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are high but falling after Tuesdayâ€™s rainfall.  Flooding of low-lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are those around the River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield. The weather forecast is unsettled, but mostly dry over the weekend, which should allow river levels to continue to fall. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 9 am tomorrow, 23/12/23.

items.description: Low lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment
items.message: River levels in the Upper River Hull catchment remain high due to recent rainfall and elevated groundwater levels. Areas most at risk include the River Hull and tributaries at Frodingham, Hempholme, Wilfholme and Burshill. River levels are expected to remain high for several days as groundwater is yet to peak in some areas. West Beck is also particularly high. We are operating pumps in the area and continue to monitor the situation. Put your flood plan into action, avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00am on Saturday 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels remain high in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected to continue on the Hundred Foot (Ouse) Washes for several days. This information is correct as of 3:30pm on 22/12/23. The causeway at Earith may have some standing water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 34 cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 38cm of water on the road. Norfolk County Council have closed Welney causeway. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Floodwater is travelling down the River Great Ouse towards the Ouse Washes which will keep levels high for several days. Avoid driving through floodwater. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, 23/12/23

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high, and close to the surface. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, with water flowing on roads, in basements or under floorboards, and affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. Water could also affect the B2141 at Chilgrove. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days (up to and including 25/12/2023). Groundwater at Chilgrove's borehole, is expected to continue falling, and water on the B2141 might reduce slightly. At the East Dean borehole, groundwater will stay at the surface. Flood impacts are expected to remain until the middle of January, and potentially longer, or affecting more people if wet weather returns. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 27/12/2023

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: The risk of flooding from the water courses in the Heighington and Dunston area has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high but steady on the Ginge Brook. Due to these high levels the risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, although it is not expected over the next couple of days. 

Light rain is possible today, 22/12/2023, but should clear away by the afternoon. River levels are expected to remain high over the next couple of days, and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated Saturday morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
This flood alert remains in force due to strong winds at high tide. The first forecast high water is at 14:45 on 22/12/23 with a level of 4.21mAOD and a Force 6 gusting force 7 westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high-water time at Hinkley. The second high water is at 03:15 am on 23/12/23 with a level of 3.94 mAOD and a Force 7 westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high-water time at Hinkley. mAOD is height above average sea level. Please refer to local tide tables.

Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at this time and conditions may apply for a period either side of the high tide. Flooding is possible for the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir.

Current high winds are exacerbating conditions on the coast. Winds are forecast to ease in the coming days. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads, and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. We are monitoring the situation closely, and this message will be updated by 10:00 am on Saturday 23/12/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high and close to the surface, but currently slowly falling at the Compton borehole. Minor groundwater flood impacts will continue, with springs affecting fields, the village green Stoughton, and rural roads including Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden and also between Cooks Lane and The Barley Mow, and the B2146 near Woodlands Lane, in Walderton. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days (up to and including 25/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to continue to slowly fall through to next week, and possibly through to the New Year. Groundwater flood impacts might reduce by a small amount by January. However, groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 27/12/2023

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are currently high but steady or falling along the lower River Kennet. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, although not expected. 

Light rain is possible today, 22/12/2023, but should clear away by the afternoon. River levels are expected to remain the same around Newbury and continue to fall around Theale, however levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated Saturday morning, 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: The River Nene has being falling steadily over night on Thursday 21st December. North Bank Road will be reopened once the Highways Authority have been able to inspect the road surface and carry out any necessary works to ensure the road is passable. There may be standing water in low lying areas and fields for several days.

items.description: River Bourne and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are remaining high at the Salisbury Bourne river gauge on the River Bourne due to the recent rainfall and additional contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels. Levels at our Ebbesbourne Wake and Salisbury gauges are receding but remain high.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Bourne, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area. The forecast is for very little rain this evening and over the week.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 4PM on 24/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in villages surrounding Andover are high and continuing to rise in response to the rainfall received in December. Groundwater is affecting cellars in Appleshaw and Hatherden, the sewer network in Penton Mewsey, and the main road in Penton Grafton. The spring at Biddesden could begin to flow from Tuesday 26/12/2023. Cellar flooding in Penton Grafton, and groundwater emergence into Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton is possible from Thursday 28/12/2023. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday 24/12/2023, dry weather is forecast. From Monday 25/12/2023 to Tuesday 26/12/2023, unsettled weather will return with up to 20mm forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels will continue to rise. If not, we expect the level to peak between Christmas and New Year. Cellar flooding in Kimpton and surface water flooding in Thruxton could occur in early January 2024. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove valuables from cellars and ensure pumps used to reduce water levels can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 27/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high and have risen 47cm in the last 3 days. Groundwater will be affecting cellars in the south end of the village and at the Dolphin Inn pub, as well as impacting the sewerage network. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday (24/12/2023), the weather is forecast to be dry. From Monday to Tuesday (26/12/2023), up to 20mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects Hursley, then groundwater levels will continue to rise. If not, then we expect the level to peak within the next few days. During the next 5 days, it is possible that cellars in upper Hursley will begin to be affected. We continue to monitor the forecast and groundwater levels. Please remove valuables from cellars, and if you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 27/12/2023.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

The next high tide is forecast to reach approximately 4.47 metres and the following, approximately 4.58 metres. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We continue to monitor the situation. We are checking the condition of defences and we will continue to monitor the forecast.

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message: In the Meon Valley, groundwater levels are high but continue to slowly fall after a week of mostly dry weather. The Winterbourne has been flowing in Meonstoke for a couple of weeks and there is a small amount of water ponded around the electricity sub-station in Rectory Lane. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday (24/12/2023), the weather is forecast to be dry. Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling during that time. However, from Monday (25/12/2023) to Tuesday (26/12/2023), the weather turns more unsettled again with up to 20mm forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the Meon Valley, groundwater levels will begin to rise again. Cellar flooding caused by groundwater remains a possibility this winter. Please remain prepared. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please check that they can operate effectively. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 27/12/2023.

items.description: River Thames from Hampton and Thames Ditton to Teddington

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

The next high tide is forecast to reach approximately 4.49 metres and the following approximately, 4.60 metres. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We continue to monitor the situation. We are checking the condition of defences and we will continue to monitor the forecast.

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have fallen back in the West Wiltshire Downs and the Vale of Wardour, but some boreholes are showing a continuing, but gentle rise further east, especially in the River Bourne catchment. By the weekend, all levels are expected to be falling slightly.
Check any property level flood resilience measures including pumps, flood barriers and airbrick covers that you may have in place and replenish stocks of sand bags. 
The weather forecast up to the New Year is for limited amounts of rainfall which makes further property flooding unlikely until into the new year when a more unsettled period is expected.
Environment Agency staff will monitor groundwater levels over the holiday and this message will be updated every 48 hours or as the situation changes. The next update will be on Friday 22nd December.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Twyford and Hensting
items.message: In Twyford and Hensting, groundwater levels are high and continue to rise. In the next 3 days, cellar flooding may begin to affect a small number of properties in Twyford and Hensting. However, we are expecting levels to begin stabilising in the next 3 days. Levels may peak just below the level we expect impacts to occur. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday (24/12/2023), the weather is forecast to be mostly dry. However, from Monday (25/12/2023) to Tuesday (26/12/2023), the weather turns more unsettled again with up to 20mm forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels will continue to rise. Minor impact flooding to Hensting Lane could occur in the next 2 weeks. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on 27/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Vernham Dean, Upton and the Bourne Valley
items.message: In the Bourne Valley, groundwater levels are high and rising. At Vernham Dean, the current rate of rise is 22cm per day. Currently, groundwater is inundating the sewerage network in Stoke. In the next 5 days, groundwater may affect a small number of cellars and the sewerage system in Upton. However, the rate of rise is slowing and levels may peak before this occurs. We do not expect significant impacts to property at Vernham Dean, Hurstbourne Tarrant, Stoke or St Marybourne until later this winter. From today until Sunday (24/12/2023), dry weather is forecast. From Monday to Tuesday (26/12/2023), up to 20mm of rainfall is forecast. If heavy rain affects the Bourne Valley, groundwater levels will continue to rise. If not, we expect the level to peak between Christmas and New Year. We continue to monitor the forecast. In Upton, please remove any valuables from cellars and if you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they can operate. We advise all residents in the Bourne Valley to remain prepared. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 27/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bramdean and Cheriton
items.message: In Bramdean and Cheriton, groundwater levels are high and continue to rise. Cellar flooding to a small number of properties in Cheriton is imminent. It is unlikely that cellar flooding will affect property in Bramdean for at least a couple of weeks. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday (24/12/2023), the weather is forecast to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels in Bramdean and Cheriton are expected to peak in the next 3 days. However, from Monday (25/12/2023) to Tuesday (26/12/2023), the weather turns more unsettled again with up to 20mm forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels will continue to rise. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on 27/12/2023.

items.description: Upper River Cam in Essex and Cambridgeshire
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The weather forecast remains unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to continue falling. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in East Kent
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Groundwater levels in East Kent are rising as a result of higher than average rainfall over the last three months. The Alkham Bourne is flowing, with large sections of upper and lower Nailbourne now also seeing flows. There are some flooding impacts being seen on low-lying land, roads and water infrastructure in and around the Elham Valley, Alkham, and Petham. Other communities in East Kent may also experience impacts this winter. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. 

Groundwater and river levels are expected to remain high until the Spring in 2024 and they are likely to respond to further rainfall. The weather forecast is largely dry until Christmas Day when we may see some further rainfall and unsettled weather towards the New Year. We continue to monitor the situation and are co-ordinating efforts with the local authorities and communities around the deployment of temporary defences. Our staff are maintaining and clearing key structures. This message will be updated by 28 December 2023, or as the situation changes. Search â€˜Kent Groundwater Situationâ€™ on gov.uk.

items.description: River Wissey in Norfolk
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The weather forecast remains unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to continue falling. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne
items.message: Groundwater levels in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne are high for the time of year. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rain (310mm) was recorded at Broughton. Within Kings Somborne levels look like they have started to stabilise. Further up the valley levels are still rising and are expected to continue rising for at least another week. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday 24/12/2023, the weather is forecast to be mostly dry. However, unsettled weather is expected to return from Monday 25/12/2023 to Tuesday 26/12/2023, with up to 20mm forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the area, then levels could rise further throughout the Christmas period and cellar flooding to a small number of properties along Winchester Road, central Kings Somborne and in Little Somborne would be possible before the New Year. Please remove valuables from cellars and if you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 27/12/2023.

items.description: Tributaries in North Derbyshire

floodArea.riverOrSea: Bradwell Brook, Dale Brook, Tideswell Brook, Warney Brook and Bentley Brook

items.message:
"River levels are rising at the Bradwell river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to begin today from 16:00, 22/12/2013, we expect river levels to stay high for the next 48 hours.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around the tributaries of the Rivers Derwent, Wye and Noe in North Derbyshire including Grinds Brook, Peakshole Water, Bradwell Brook, Stoke Brook, Bar Brook, Tideswell Brook, Warney Brook, Bentley Brook, Via Gellia and Lea Brook.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 09:00 23/12/2023"
